fields.descriptive_line: Drawing, 	Deux avocats (La dignité de rang), by Honoré Daumier, French School, late 19th century
fields.physical_description: A study of two lawyers walking past each other haughtily.  Both are wearing traditional French lawyer outfits of robes and cylindrical hats.
fields.title: Deux avocats (La dignité de rang)
fields.materials_techniques: Graphite, pen and wash on transparent paper
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C, case MB2D, shelf SH37, box IONIDES3
Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.public_access_description: Honoré Daumier (1808-79) illustrator, sculptor and painter, Daumier first became familiar with the Palace of Justice at the age of just 13 where he worked as a bailiff's assistant.   As a lithogrpaher, from the early 1830s, he drew on average 2 illustrations a week, satirising the law courts and the monarchy.  Whilst working at one publication  Le Charivari  under Phillipon, he was imprisoned by King Louis-Philippe for six months (1831) for his depiction of him as a Gargantua sitting on a commode.  Phillipon, the printer Delaporte and the publisher Aubert were all imprisoned for their part in satirising the King.  Censorship of the press was brought into force on several occassions, finally forcing Daumier to aim his satire at Bourgeois society instead of recording the corruption and pomposity of the legal profession.
fields.bibliography: K.E. Maison, Honore Daumier,Catalogue Raisonne of the Paintings, Watercolours and Drawings, vol. II,The Watercolours and Drawings, Thames and Hudson, London 1904, p. 195, cat no. 587, illus. plate 212 The following is the full entry of the text: Deux avocats Plate 212 (La dignité de rang) Crayon, pen and wash, on tracing paper, 21.5 x 12.5 cm. Unsigned. London, Victoria and Albert Museum, ionides Collection [1901]. PROVENANCE: C.A. Ionides. REFERENCE: Fuchs 195a. While the figure on the left appears freely drawn, the one on the right is traced (although not with the artist's usual sureness and verve). After long hesitation, i believe the drawing to be genuine, but certainly 'below standard'. Basil S. Long, Catalogue of the Constantine Alexander Ionides Collection, vol. I, Paintings in Oil, Tempera and Water-Colour together with certain of the Drawings, London 1925, p.16. cat. no. 121 E. Fuchs, Der Maler Daumier, Munich, 1927, cat. no. 195a.
fields.history_note: C.A. Ionides, by whom bequeathed in 1900
fields.historical_context_note: Honoré Daumier (1808-79), lithographer, painter and sculptor. Daumier first became familiar with the Palace of Justice at the age of just 13 where he worked as a bailiff's assistant. As a lithogrpaher, from the early 1830s, he drew on average 2 illustrations a week, satirising the law courts and the monarchy. Whilst working at one publication Le Charivari under Phillipon, he was imprisoned by King Louis-Philippe for his depiction of him as a Gargantua sitting on a commode. Phillipon, the printer Delaporte and the publisher Aubert were all imprisoned for their part in satirising the King. Censorship of the press was brought into force on several occassions, finally forcing Daumier to aim his satire at Bourgeois society instead. This study can be atttributed to Daumier, illustrating one of his most known subjects; lawyers. His vigorous style lent to his skill as a caricaturist, which he demonstrated in such progressive publications as La Silhouette , Le Charivari and Caricature . This image is very similar in composition to other drawings, for example, Deux Avocats (Daumier 1808-1879, Reunion des Musees Nationaux, 1999, p. 370, pl. 219)and Deux collegues (or Les Confreres)(Daumier 1808-1879, Reunion des Musees Nationaux, 1999, p. 370, pl. 220) both showing lawyers walking past each other, a recurrent theme that he used. Daumier became known as a painter after his death. During his life he was more known for his satirical and anti-monarchist lithographic illustrations. Many sketches represent similar subjects of lawyers passing, waving at each other or walking together (Musee des Beaux Arts de Reims; Williamstown, Sterling and Francine Clark Institute).
